story.kicker_image_caption: Elk charging the tourist. Original photo: Video screengrabs
story.storykicker: An elk at Yellowstone National Park lost its cool when a woman came far too close to click its picture. What it did after led the woman to promise "that won't happen again".
story.storybody:
If you have ever been irked by a camera being pointed at you, you will empathise with this animal.

An elk at Yellowstone National Park lost its cool when a woman came far too close to click its picture. As people around start to warn her, the elk came charging at the woman.

It's not quite clear if the elk got to attack her or not, as the camera switched angles a little too late. When the woman comes back in the frame, she is lying on her back on the ground and the elk is standing at a distant.

In a video posted on Facebook by tour guide Jody Tibbitts, a man in the background can be heard shouting, "Did you get that on video?", as the animal walks back into the woods (may we say) like a boss.

A spokesperson of the National Park Service told ABC News that those looking to get close-up photos of animals can endanger themselves and wildlife, reports AP.

Visitors are asked to stay at least 100 yards from bears and wolves and at least 25 yards from all other wildlife.

But some get carried away by their passion for photography, for wildlife, or by the idea of having cool pictures on their social networking profiles.

This woman, however, learned her lesson. Near the end of the video, you can hear her promise "that won't happen again".

Take a look at the how the elk came charging to take a swing at her:
story.magazinekicker: An elk at Yellowstone National Park lost its cool when a woman came far too close to click its picture. What it did after led the woman to promise "that won't happen again".
story.shortheadline: Watch: This elk just taught photo-taking tourists who come too close a lesson
